TextView.android:text: 11 Alphabet Review Here are the nine shorthand strokes you studied in Lesson 1. How rapidly can you read them?
2 O, R, L In this paragraph you will study three extremely useful strokes o, r, l.
O The shorthand stroke for o is a small deep hook.
R The shorthand stroke for r is a short forward curve.
L The shorthand stroke for 1 is a longer forward curve about three times as long as the stroke for r.
â€¢ Observe how these three strokes are derived from their longhand forms.

â€¢ Observe that in the words in the third column, the o is placed on its side before n and m. This enables us to obtain smoother, more easily written outlines than we would obtain if we wrote the o upright in these and similar words.
â€¢ Observe that f-r, as in freed, and f-l, as in floor, are written with one sweep of the pen, with no stop between the f and the r or 1.

3 H,-ing The letter h is a dot placed above the following vowel. With few exceptions, h occurs at the beginning of a word, Ing, which almost always occurs at the end of a word, is also represented by a dot.
4 Long I The shorthand stroke for the long sound of i, as in my, is a large broken circle.

5 Omission of Minor Vowels Many words in the English language contain vowels that are sounded only slightly or are slurred. For example, the word even is really pronounced e-vn; meter is pronounced met-r. (The dictionary calls these minor vowels "schwas.") These vowels are omitted in shorthand when their omission does not detract from facility of writing or from legibility.
